WRITING.TEXT: They're a plague to coral reefs. Ox gall is precisely what it says on the tin (I'm a printmaker and need the same substance for wholly different reasons, that's how I came to learn this bit), the injections actually contain TCBS agar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thiosulfate-citrate-bile_salts-sucrose_agar), a medium of which ox gall is a constituting ingredient. TCBS is the perfect nourishment for vibrio bacteria (the same genus to which human cholera pathogens belong), a small and usually harmless amount the starfish contain anyway. The bacteria then multiply massively, leading to a fatal infection that can even spread to uninjected individuals. Nifty. Other treatments with other poison was less successful due to the starfish's extraordinary regenerative abilities. Killing them manually (dissecting, clubbing, whatever) is even more inefficient and also gets the divers injured frequently. Yup, the starfish are poisonous as well (and really hideous. And they like to munch on corals).
